newsitem.title: INDIA: INDIAN CINEMA - Latest weekly box office.
newsitem.headline: INDIAN CINEMA - Latest weekly box office.

text.p: INDIAN FILM BOX OFFICE REPORT FOR WEEK TO DEC 12, 1996

RAJA HINDUSTANI, a film by Dharmesh Darshan with Aamir Khan and Karisma Kapoor playing the lead roles looks like overtaking last year's blockbuster DILWALE DULHANIYA LE JAYENGE (DDLJ) in overall collections.
The film, with hit music by Nadeem Shravan, crossed the 100 million rupee mark in collections with 170 prints in four weeks while DDLJ needed 200 prints.

There seems to be no immediate competition to RAJA HINDUSTANI in the near future as producers of big-budget films have decided not to release any film in the Bombay circuit till the state government reverses its stand on entertainment tax.
The government plans to increase the tax to 100 percent from January 1, 1997 from 50 percent at present.
Producers and exhibitors of films have warned that all theatres in the state will down shutters indefinitely in protest unless the government changes its decision.

Amitabh Bachchan Corporation Limited, which opened its account in the distribution sector with two major hits, BOMBAY and BANDIT QUEEN, released its first production TERA MERE SAPNE (Dreams of one another).

However the first week's collections were not impressive with the film doing ggod business in only some cities. Bombay recorded business of 88 percent. Calcutta refused to divulge figures because of poor collections.
Inspired by TRADING PLACES, TERE MERA SAPNE directed by debutant Joy Augustine stars Chandrachur Singh (of MAACHIS) Simran and newcomers Arshad Warsi and Priya Gill.
Viju Shah's music and Arshad Warsi's performance are noteworthy.
HUM HAIN KALNAYAK (we are villains), with new faces, released in Bombay and three other cities was rejected by the audience due to its poor quality in all areas.
RAKSHAK and DASTAK, both dropped about 50 percent in the second week. GHATAK was steady while there was a slight drop in the collections of MAACHIS and CHHOTE SARKAR.
Among English movies, INDEPENDENCE DAY leads the pack with only a marginal decline in collections while ERASER has lost its box-office appeal.
TWISTER opened all over the country to a good response.
CRIMSON TIDE registered average collections in its one week run in Bombay.
